intro: Acalypha caperonioides var. galpinii, commonly known as the Cape York beauty, is a flowering plant native to parts of Australia. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its striking, palmate leaves that are often brightly colored. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are usually green or yellow, surrounded by modified leaves called bracts. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal or wetland areas. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it can be invasive in certain regions.
